Headline.Para: Rivals Duel for White House Communications Job; Two aides compete to succeed Hope Hicks; VA Secretary David Shulkin's job remains in limbo

LeadPara.Para: WASHINGTON—A fierce internal rivalry is unfolding at the White House over the communications director job, with some aides warning they will quit depending on whom President Donald Trump chooses to fill the post.

No senior position in the White House has seen as much volatility as communications director. Four people have held the title since the inauguration, with a fresh vacancy opening up following Hope Hicks's announcement last month that she would be leaving the White House.

TailParas.Para: Uncertainty over that hire comes as Mr. Trump reshapes his senior staff, cabinet and his private legal team handling the investigation of any ties between his 2016 campaign and Russia.
For weeks, Mr. Trump has been mulling whether to oust his Veterans Affairs Secretary, David Shulkin, people close to the White House have said.

Dr. Shulkin has faced scrutiny following an inspector general report that said he misspent taxpayer funds during a trip to Europe. The report found that he improperly accepted free tickets to the Wimbledon tennis tournament in England and that taxpayers improperly paid part of his wife's expenses.
Dr. Shulkin has since repaid his wife's expenses and made a contribution to the U.S. Treasury equal to the value of the tennis tickets.

Asked about Dr. Shulkin's standing on Monday, White House spokesman Raj Shah said he hadn't received an update from Mr. Trump in the past several hours. "I haven't asked the president about it directly today, so I don't want to comment on it," he said.
A spokesman for Dr. Shulkin, Curtis Cashour, said: "There are no personnel changes to announce" at the VA.
Such calibrated responses to personnel questions have become more common lately as the status of Trump subordinates changes from day to day and sometimes hour to hour.

National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster was dismissed last week, only days after the president denied reports that the three-star Army general was on his way out, and weeks after Gen. McMaster told friends that Mr. Trump had asked him to stay on the job through the November elections.

After the announcement last week that Joseph DiGenova would be joining Mr. Trump's legal team in the Russia probe, a Trump attorney said over the weekend that Mr. DiGenova wouldn't be hired after all due to a conflict of interest. Now, Mr. Trump's lawyers are scrambling to recruit more attorneys as they negotiate with special counsel Robert Mueller over the terms of Mr. Trump's possible testimony.

In an interview Monday on MSNBC, former Solicitor General Ted Olson, who declined an offer to join Mr. Trump's legal team, said of the White House: "This is turmoil, it's chaos, it's confusion—it's not good for anything,"

Mr. Trump, a former reality TV star who keeps close watch on his press and communications shops, has been considering outside candidates for a new director, but has had trouble finding a suitable fit.

One person he has spoken to in recent weeks is Bill Shine, a former Fox News executive, but Mr. Shine wasn't interested in the job, people familiar with the matter said. Mr. Shine, reached by phone Monday, declined to comment.

Inside the West Wing, aides are uneasy about a competition playing out between two colleagues: Mercedes Schlapp, now a top White House communications adviser, and Tony Sayegh, who heads the public affairs department under Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and is a former Fox News contributor.

Both are in the running to succeed Ms. Hicks, though Mr. Trump is also considering installing another top adviser, Kellyanne Conway, at least on an interim basis, people familiar with the matter said. Ms. Conway could be a consensus choice who helps Mr. Trump sidestep the fissures between the Schlapp and Sayegh factions.

The job isn't an easy one, as some alumni have said. Speaking at Georgetown University last year after serving just three months in the communications post, Michael Dubke said he felt he was "always looking over both shoulders"—at what the news media was reporting and what Mr. Trump was tweeting.
It is unclear when Mr. Trump will pick his new communications director, who oversees about 30 people.

Those loyal to Ms. Schlapp said they predict a wave of departures if Mr. Trump bypasses her in favor of Mr. Sayegh. They said that Ms. Schlapp has earned the promotion, after laying out strategies for Mr. Trump's infrastructure program and other initiatives.
Ms. Schlapp declined a request for comment, as did Ms. Hicks.
Mr. Sayegh's chief achievement was helping devise the communications plan that helped usher the tax-code overhaul into law last year, people close to him said.

One person familiar with Mr. Sayegh's views said that he believes the communications team hasn't always served the president well, and that Mr. Trump deserves more of the communications strategies that proved effective in the tax fight. His view is that some people are "just filling jobs" rather than devising "creative" approaches to advancing Mr. Trump's agenda, this person said.

Hogan Gidley, a White House spokesman, said: "Tony and Mercy work well together and they have mutual respect for each other. It's about furthering the president's agenda and both of them want to do that."
Michael C. Bender contributed to this article.
